1320.study_design: Cross-sectional study examining associations between dietary factors, oral microbiota, and recurrent oral ulcer (ROU) in 579 community-based participants from the Central China Cohort
1320.statistical_methods: Logistic regression, Wilcoxon rank sum test, Chi-squared test, PERMANOVA, MaAsLin (multivariate analysis by linear models), ANCOM-BC, mediation analysis, Benjamini-Hochberg FDR correction, PICRUSt2 functional prediction, centered log-ratio transformation, PCoA with Bray-Curtis and robust Aitchison distances

bacteria_relationships.notes: Positively associated with ROU. Belongs to phylum Fusobacteria. Previously found to be associated with active oral ulcers and isolated from blood cultures of patients with oral mucosa lesions.
Positively associated with ROU. Belongs to phylum Actinobacteria. Implicated in oral abscesses and correlated with gingivitis and periapical lesions.

Positively associated with ROU. Belongs to phylum Actinobacteria. Also positively correlated with ROU and inversely correlated with hPDI. Included in composite bacterial score. May play role in caries production.

Positively associated with ROU. Lower in highest hPDI tertile (p < 0.05). Identified as potential mediator between hPDI and ROU with mediation proportion of 10.77%. TM7 bacteria positively associated with inflammatory mucosal diseases and periodontal mucosal infections.
Positively associated with ROU. Previously associated with periodontal health.
Inversely associated with ROU. Relative abundance significantly different between extreme tertiles of red meat intake (p < 0.05).

Inversely associated with ROU. More abundant in participants with higher hPDI and less abundant with higher red meat intake. Identified as potential mediator between hPDI and ROU (mediation proportion 11.04%) and between red meat intake and ROU (mediation proportion ~14%). Included in composite bacterial score.
Inversely associated with ROU. Included in composite bacterial score. Abiotrophia defectiva considered beneficial for periodontal health.
Inversely associated with ROU. Identified as potential mediator between hPDI and ROU with mediation proportion of 17.23%. Included in composite bacterial score.

Inversely associated with ROU (one of the 11 inversely associated genera). Relative abundance significantly different between extreme tertiles of red meat intake (p < 0.05). Listed as 'Streptobacillu' in text, likely Streptobacillus.

Inversely associated with ROU (one of the 11 inversely associated genera). Relative abundance significantly different between extreme tertiles of egg intake (p < 0.05). Association with hPDI only significant among females.
Inversely associated with ROU. Identified as a taxon correlated with periodontitis in previous studies. Mentioned in discussion as one of the genera inversely correlated with oral ulcers.
One of the 16 ROU-associated genera. Direction not explicitly stated in available text. Link between Bergeyella and red meat was solely observed among males.
Mentioned as the phylum to which several positively ROU-associated genera (e.g., Leptotrichia) mainly belong. Not directly tested at phylum level.
Mentioned as the phylum to which several positively ROU-associated genera (e.g., Actinomyces, Atopobium) mainly belong. Not directly tested at phylum level.
Discussion states that several genera negatively correlated with ROU primarily belonged to the Firmicutes phylum, consistent with previous research. Not directly tested at phylum level.
Cited from previous literature (reference [5]) as having decreased abundance in saliva microbiota of patients with ROU. Not measured in this study's results.
Cited from previous literature (reference [5]) as having increased abundance in saliva microbiota of patients with ROU. Not measured in this study's results.
Mentioned in discussion as a beneficial bacterial species for periodontal health from previous literature. Species-level identification not confirmed in this study (genus Abiotrophia was identified).

extraction_metadata.potential_missing_data: The paper states 16 genera were associated with ROU (p-FDR < 0.20), with 5 positively and 11 inversely associated. Only 5 positively associated genera are explicitly named (Leptotrichia, Actinomyces, Atopobium, TM7x, Corynebacterium). Of the 11 inversely associated genera, only approximately 7 are explicitly named (Wolinella, Olsenella, Abiotrophia, unclassified Muribaculaceae, Streptobacillus, Rikenellaceae RC9 gut group, Peptococcus). Bergeyella is mentioned but direction unclear. Approximately 3-4 genera from the 16 total are not explicitly named in the available text - they may be visible in Figure 2C heatmap which is not fully accessible.
limitations: Cross-sectional design precludes causal inference
16S rRNA gene sequencing lacks species-level resolution
FDR threshold of p < 0.20 is relatively liberal
Exact relative abundance values and effect sizes for individual genera not provided in text
Figure 2C heatmap contains full list of 16 genera but individual genus names not all extractable from text alone
Some genera mentioned only in supplementary tables (S7-S9) which are not fully available
Dietary data based on self-reported food frequency questionnaire with potential recall bias
Streptococcus salivarius and Capnocytophaga sputigena cited from prior literature, not from this study's results

230.study_design: Cross-sectional study characterizing aerosol particles and bioaerosol microbiota sources during dental procedures in an open-concept dental clinic. Bayesian source tracking (SourceTracker2) was used to estimate contribution of patient nasal and salivary fluids to operator bioaerosol exposure.
230.sample_size: 184 samples from 51 dental procedures (51 personal samplers, 51 nasal swabs, 51 saliva samples, 11 preprocedural air samples, 20 corridor samplers)
230.statistical_methods: Shapiro-Wilk normality test, Kruskal-Wallis nonparametric test, Pearson correlation, ANOSIM of Jaccard and Bray-Curtis indices, ANOVA with Tukey post-hoc HSD, Bayesian modeling (SourceTracker2), DADA2 for ASV bias correction, SILVA138 classifier for species assignment, LoopSeq full-length 16S rDNA sequencing

extraction_metadata.potential_missing_data: The paper does not report specific bacterial taxa with directional changes (increased/decreased). It reports 545 phylotypes condensed from 3,902 ASVs, 219 of which were identifiable through the Human Oral Microbiome Database (HOMD), but no individual bacterial names or changes are listed. The study focused on source tracking (what percentage of bioaerosol comes from patient saliva, nasal fluids, ambient air, or unknown sources) rather than characterizing specific microbial taxa or disease-associated changes. Staphylococcus aureus is mentioned only in the context of a nasal swab validation method, not as a finding.
limitations: This is not a disease characterization or treatment study - it is an environmental/occupational exposure study of dental bioaerosols
No specific bacterial taxa are reported with directional changes (increased/decreased)
The study reports community-level differences (ANOSIM) between sample types but does not list individual taxa
Detailed taxonomic data may exist in supplemental materials not provided
13 of 64 personal samplers were excluded due to technical issues
All personal samplers from tooth preparation without rubber dam were excluded due to lab errors

1529.study_design: Four-group mouse model: Control (Con), Rifaximin only (Rif), Influenza A virus infection only (Flu), and Rifaximin + Influenza A virus (Rif+Flu). BALB/c mice infected with H1N1 IAV with or without rifaximin supplementation (50 mg/kg). Fecal microbiota analyzed at day 4 post-infection via 16S rRNA V3-V4 sequencing and targeted metabolomics.
1529.sample_size: 48 BALB/c mice total, 12 per group; n=4 per group for 16S rRNA sequencing at day 4
1529.statistical_methods: One-way ANOVA using SPSS 25.0, Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for normality, LEfSe analysis for differential bacterial abundance, Wilcoxon test, PERMANOVA for beta-diversity, PICRUSt for functional prediction

bacteria_relationships.notes: Rif group had significantly lower Firmicutes compared to Con, Rif+Flu, and Flu groups. No significant difference between Con and Flu groups for this phylum.
Rif group had significantly higher Bacteroidetes compared to Con, Rif+Flu, and Flu groups.
No notable distinction observed among the four groups.
Patescibacteria was significantly lower in Rif+Flu and Flu groups compared to Con group.
Actinobacteria was higher in Rif and Con groups compared to Rif+Flu group.
Mentioned as making up a smaller percentage; no specific quantitative data or significance testing reported.
Mentioned as making up a smaller percentage; no specific quantitative data or significance testing reported.
Dominant genus; Flu group had highest abundance. No specific statistical test reported for this comparison in the text.
Dominant genus listed; Rif+Flu had highest abundance, Rif had lowest. No specific statistical test reported.
LEfSe LDA score = 4.3. Described as a probiotic in the abstract. Significantly reduced in Flu group compared to Con group.
LEfSe LDA score = 3.59. Described as a probiotic in the abstract. Significantly reduced in Flu group compared to Con group.
LEfSe LDA score = 3.08. Significantly reduced in Flu group compared to Con group.
LEfSe LDA score = 4.00. Significantly reduced in Flu group compared to Con group.
LEfSe LDA score = 3.12. Dominant in Flu group compared to Con group.
LEfSe LDA score = 2.97. Dominant in Flu group compared to Con group.
Increased in Rif+Flu group compared to Flu group. Associated with better response to immunotherapy and tryptophan metabolism per discussion.
Increased in Rif+Flu group compared to Flu group.
Increased in Rif+Flu group compared to Flu group.

extraction_metadata.potential_missing_data: Figures 3a-b and 4a-b show top 10 phyla and genera respectively in heatmaps and bar charts, but only a subset are discussed with statistical significance in the text. Additional genera and phyla visible in figures may not be fully extracted. Supplementary figures S2c and S2d contain additional LEfSe results that are referenced but not fully detailed in the main text.
contradictions_found: The abstract states rifaximin reversed the reduction of Lachnoclostridium and Ruminococcaceae_UCG-013, but the results section only shows these were decreased in Flu vs Con - the Rif+Flu group comparison for these specific genera is not explicitly reported with statistics in the results.
Discussion mentions Bacteroides reduction in small intestine from prior H5N1 study and Lactobacillus increase, which is consistent with their Flu group data but the context differs (H5N1 vs H1N1).
limitations: Small sample size for 16S sequencing (n=4 per group)
No multiple comparison correction explicitly mentioned beyond one-way ANOVA
Supplementary figures contain additional data not fully accessible from the text
Some quantitative values for genus-level comparisons are not provided as exact percentages for all groups
The paper does not clearly distinguish which genera changes in Rif+Flu vs Flu represent reversal of disease effect vs novel rifaximin effect

1320.study_design: Cross-sectional study of community-based participants comparing those with Recurrent Oral Ulcer (ROU) to those without, analyzing saliva microbiota and dietary factors.
1320.statistical_methods: Wilcoxon rank sum test, Chi-squared test, Logistic regression, MaAsLin (Multivariate Association with Linear Models), ANCOM-BC, Mediation analysis, Benjamini–Hochberg FDR correction (p-FDR < 0.20).

bacteria_relationships.notes: Alpha diversity metric (richness)
Genera positively associated mainly belonged to this phylum
Genera positively associated mainly belonged to this phylum
Genera negatively correlated primarily belonged to this phylum

Positively associated with ROU
Positively correlated with ROU
Positively correlated with ROU; identified as mediator
Listed in discussion as positively associated with ROU in this study
Inversely associated with ROU
Inversely associated with ROU; identified as mediator
Inversely associated with ROU
Inversely correlated with ROU; identified as mediator
Mentioned in discussion as one of the genera inversely correlated with oral ulcers in this study

Identified as an ROU-associated genus (one of the 16), but specific direction relative to ROU not explicitly stated in text (only its relationship to diet is detailed). Likely decreased based on grouping with Wolinella/Olsenella in diet analysis.
Identified as an ROU-associated genus (one of the 16), but specific direction relative to ROU not explicitly stated in text.

extraction_metadata.potential_missing_data: Paper states 16 genera were associated with ROU. We extracted 13 specific genera (Leptotrichia, Actinomyces, Atopobium, TM7x, Corynebacterium, Wolinella, Olsenella, Abiotrophia, unclassified Muribaculaceae, Peptococcus, Streptobacillu, Rikenellaceae RC9 gut group, Bergeyella). 3 genera are missing from the text provided.
limitations: Some bacteria (Streptobacillu, Rikenellaceae RC9 gut group, Bergeyella) are identified as ROU-associated in the text, but their specific direction (increased/decreased) is not explicitly stated, only their relationship to diet.
Streptobacillu appears to be a typo for Streptobacillus.

230.study_design: Cross-sectional study characterizing particle size, concentration, and microbial source tracking (nasal vs. salivary) in dental aerosols during 7 different procedures in an open-concept clinic
230.sample_size: 184 samples (51 personal samplers, 51 nasal swabs, 51 saliva samples, 11 preprocedural air samples, 20 corridor samplers)
230.statistical_methods: Shapiro–Wilk normality test, Kruskal–Wallis test, Pearson correlation, Bayesian modeling (SourceTracker2), ANOSIM (Jaccard and Bray–Curtis indices), ANOVA with Tukey post-hoc HSD

extraction_metadata.potential_missing_data: The paper analyzes the microbiome using 16S rDNA sequencing and mentions identifying 545 phylotypes and 219 identifiable through HOMD, but it does not list specific bacterial taxon names (genera or species) in the provided text. It focuses entirely on particle sizes and the percentage of reads attributed to specific sources (nasal vs. saliva vs. ambient).
limitations: No specific bacterial taxa were named in the Results or Discussion sections.
Staphylococcus aureus was mentioned in the Methods section only to validate the nasal swab sampling technique, not as a study result.

1529.study_design: Animal model (BALB/c mice) of Influenza A Virus (H1N1) infection with and without Rifaximin supplementation. Groups: Control (Con), Rifaximin+Flu (Rif+Flu), Rifaximin only (Rif), Flu only (Flu).
1529.sample_size: 48 mice total (n=4 per group for 16S rRNA sequencing)
1529.statistical_methods: Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for normality, one-way ANOVA for multiple groups, LEfSe analysis for biomarkers (LDA scores), Wilcoxon rank-sum test.

limitations: Sample size for microbiome analysis was small (n=4).
